thread.title: SpeedCast buys NewSat’s Mawson Lakes facility
thread.title_full: SpeedCast buys NewSat’s Mawson Lakes facility | Business News | Business and Finance News | | The Advertiser

author: VALERINA CHANGARATHIL
title: SpeedCast buys NewSat’s Mawson Lakes facility
text:
HONG KONG-based global satellite services provider SpeedCast has bought the Adelaide and Perth assets, equipment and contracts of failed company NewSat for about $12 million.
SpeedCast’s NSW arm reached a deal with the receivers of the company, which also including retaining 20 NewSat high-skilled employees.
The land and buildings at NewSat’s teleport facilities in Adelaide and Perth and NewSat’s customer base means SpeedCast gets access to a strong reseller network, blue-chip enterprise customers and government customers.
“These will complement SpeedCast’s existing infrastructure in the region, provide expansion capabilities and enhance its ability to deliver high quality satellite communications services to its
energy, government and telecom customers in Asia-Pacific, Middle-East and Africa,” SpeedCast said in a statement.
“NewSat’s state-of-the-art teleport infrastructure and highly experienced operations and engineering team also enhances our ability to serve our customers in Asia-Pacific, thus strengthening our leadership position in the region, while giving us new capabilities to provide services into Middle East and Africa; it represents an attractive platform for future growth,” said SpeedCast chief executive Pierre-Jean Beylier.
NewSat made revenues of $22 million in the financial year ended June 30.
It said the deal has been funded using available cash and the company’s existing debt facilities with no need for any change to its lending terms.
NewSat failed in April - following years of planning a $600 million plus project to launch an Australian satellite, Jabiru 1, funded through $US300 million from the US Export-Import Bank and shareholders.
In May, NewSat’s receivers McGrathNicol engaged US-based Peter J. Solomon Company to conduct a recapitalisation or sale process, which would include Jabiru-1.
US satellite builder Lockheed Martin, which had built 75 per cent of the satellite, has not released it for sale.
NewSat, still a listed Australian Securities Exchange entity, made a $39.7 million loss in the six months to December 31, and had $300 million in outstanding loan repayments when it sank.
It is understood a $US250 million bid by Malaysian-based Measat also failed.
Administrators PPB Advisory will now complete investigations into whether NewSat was traded while insolvent.
